title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on 550th Falcon 9 rocket
summary: The Starlink 11-5 mission will be the 95th flight in 2025 supporting the low Earth orbit internet constellation. Liftoff from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base is scheduled for 7:16 a.m. PDT (10:16 a.m. EDT / 1416 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing to launch its 550th Falcon 9 mission since the rocket's debut in 2010. The launch from California will add 28 more broadband internet satellites to the company's Starlink constellation. The 28 Starlink V2 Mini satellites will be deployed from the Falcon 9 rocket’s second stage about an hour after liftoff.

title: Elon Musk just declared war on NASA’s acting administrator, apparently
summary: "Sean said that NASA might benefit from being part of the Cabinet."
detailed_news: SpaceX founder Elon Musk referred to the interim head of the space agency, Sean Duffy, as “Sean Dummy” Musk later added, “The person responsible for America’s space program can’t have a 2 digit IQ.” This is all pretty bonkers, so I want to try to contextualize what I believe is going on behind the scenes. NASA administrator Sean Duffy said he was reworking the agency’s lunar lander contracts because SpaceX had fallen behind. Duffy sought to demonstrate to the rest of the space community that he was willing to stand up to SpaceX. Musk channeled his inner Trump and called out ‘Sean Dummy’ A fierce, behind-the-scenes battle rages on among camps supporting Duffy and Isaacman to decide the leadership of NASA. In the meantime, NASA is twisting in the wind, trying to run in molasses while wearing lead shoes as China marches onward and upward.

title: NASA Opens Competition for Artemis III Lunar Lander
summary:
NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy revealed that the agency is reopening the contract for the…
The post NASA Opens Competition for Artemis III Lunar Lander appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: NASA is reopening the contract for the first U.S. crewed lunar landing since the 1970s. The decision marks a significant shift in NASA’s Artemis program, which seeks to establish a sustainable human presence on the Moon. The move aims to accelerate the Artemis III mission and ensure American astronauts return to the Moon's surface. SpaceX CEO Elon Musk downplayed the urgency of beating China, advocating instead for long-term sustainability. Lockheed Martin indicated it has been quietly developing a “safe solution to return humans to the Moon as quickly as possible” The announcement has left many questions unanswered, including the timeline for the new competition, proposal deadlines, and funding sources.

summary:

The post EU to Roll Out European Space Shield Initiative in 2026 appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The European Space Shield is a new initiative aimed at protecting space assets and services against ‘growing threats’ The initiative will complement the dual-use space capabilities provided by the European Union. The European Drone Defence Initiative and the Eastern Flank Watch have been identified as priority flagship programmes to be rolled out in the first quarter of 2026.

title: ESA-supported test leads to better in-flight connectivity
summary: Better in-flight streaming and video-calling might just become more accessible thanks to a project supported by the European Space Agency (ESA). Building upon the success of an experiment for a new type of antenna terminal together with ESA, Viasat – a global leader in satellite communications – now plans to commercialise its new in-flight connectivity solution called Viasat Amara.
detailed_news: Viasat plans to commercialise its new in-flight connectivity solution called Viasat Amara. It has a dual-beam phased array antenna that provides both better access to video calling (a latency-sensitive use), as well as video streaming such as watching a football match. This is possible because the antenna can connect to satellites both in low Earth orbit and in geostationary orbit, depending on what is needed.

title: Coming Soon: ESA Student Internships 2026
summary: Are you ready to take your first step into the space sector? The countdown has begun for the launch of the European Space Agency's 2026 Student Internship Programme, and you could be part of it. Applications open the first week of November.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency's 2026 Student Internship Programme opens in November. If you're passionate about engineering, science, IT, business, economics or social sciences, ESA offers a unique opportunity to gain hands-on experience at one of the world's most prestigious space organisations. Applications open the first week of November.

title: Sentinel-4 offers first glimpses of air pollutants
summary: The new Copernicus Sentinel-4 mission has delivered its first images, highlighting concentrations of atmospheric nitrogen dioxide, sulphur dioxide and ozone. Despite being preliminary, these images mark a major milestone in Europe’s ability to monitor air quality all the way from geostationary orbit, 36 000 kilometres above Earth.
detailed_news: The Copernicus Sentinel-4 mission has delivered its first images, highlighting concentrations of atmospheric nitrogen dioxide, sulphur dioxide and ozone. Despite being preliminary, these images mark a major milestone in Europe’s ability to monitor air quality all the way from geostationary orbit, 36 000 kilometres above Earth. Ozone high up in the stratosphere plays a crucial role in shielding life on Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation. But ozone in the lower atmosphere acts as a pollutant, contributing to poor air quality and respiratory problems. Overall ozone levels here are within the expected range. The large-scale distribution, featuring a maximum over the Balkans and Greece and a minimum over the Baltic region, is consistent with patterns detected on the same day.

title: The mystery object that struck a plane in flight? It was probably a weather balloon
summary: WindBorne says its balloons are compliant with all applicable airspace regulations.
detailed_news: WindBorne Systems co-founder Kai Marshland says he thinks the plane was hit by a balloon. The company has a fleet of global sounding balloons that fly various vertical profiles around the world, gathering atmospheric data. WindBorne says its balloons are compliant with all applicable airspace regulations. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the collision.

title: NASA’s acting leader seeks to keep his job with new lunar lander announcement
summary: "The president wants to make sure we beat the Chinese."
detailed_news: NASA acting administrator Sean Duffy said SpaceX has fallen behind in its efforts to develop the Starship vehicle as a lunar lander. Duffy indirectly acknowledged that NASA’s projected target of a 2027 crewed lunar landing is no longer achievable. He said he intended to expand the competition to develop a lander capable of carrying humans down to the Moon. NASA would not easily be able to rip up its existing HLS contracts with SpaceX and Blue Origin. SpaceX founder Elon Musk, responding to Duffy’s comments, seemed to relish the challenge posed by industry competitors. “SpaceX is moving like lightning compared to the rest of the space industry,” Musk said on the social media site he owns.

title: Duffy to Open Up Artemis HLS Contract to Ensure U.S. Beats China Back to the Moon
summary: In interviews on Fox News and CNBC today, Acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy said he is opening up the contract for a Human Landing System (HLS) to get Americans back […]
detailed_news: NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy said he is opening up the contract for a Human Landing System (HLS) to get Americans back on the Moon before China gets there. Duffy wants competition and innovation from Blue Origin and other U.S. companies. He also acknowledged publicly for the first time that Artemis III will not launch in mid-2027, the most recent target. Former NASA astronaut Bob Behnken, now Vice President of Exploration and Technology Strategy for Lockheed Martin Space, told SpacePolicyOnline.com that the company has been analyzing HLS options with a cross-industry team all year. In a reply to one of Duffy’s posts, Elon Musk said SpaceX is “moving like lightning compared to the rest of the space industry” and “Starship will end up doing the whole Moon mission.” SpaceX and Blue Origin are working on landing missions on the Moon. The goal is to get Americans back there by the end of Trump’s term on January 20, 2029 and before China. The plan is to alternate between the two companies for one NASA lunar landing mission per year thereafter. NASA confirmed to SpacePolicyOnline.com last week that Duffy has been interviewing candidates, including Isaacman, to be the permanent Administrator. But the WSJ is first to report that Duffy actually wants to keep the job himself. This article has been updated to reflect the new information.

title: Launch Roundup: SpaceX to launch first expendable Falcon 9 since January
summary:
SpaceX dominates this week’s launch manifest with up to four missions aboard Falcon 9 vehicles,…
The post Launch Roundup: SpaceX to launch first expendable Falcon 9 since January appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX dominates this week’s launch manifest with up to four missions aboard Falcon 9 vehicles. One of which will be the first expendable mission for the rocket since January, and another carrying 29 Starlink v2 Mini satellites for the first time. There are no other international missions scheduled at the time of publishing. Persistent bad weather expected throughout this week at the Tanegashima Space Center has pushed this launch to the weekend. The first Falcon 9 launch of the week will launch from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) on Wednesday, Oct. 22. Onboard will be the second of two SPAINSAT NG (“New Generation”) satellites, which replace the current SpainSat and XTAR-EUR communications satellites in geostationary orbit. This second-generation constellation is operator Hisdesat’s largest project yet, incorporating modern technical advances in communications. An additional Starlink mission is scheduled to launch from SLC-4E at the Vandenberg Space Force Base on Monday, Oct. 27. Another batch of 28 Starlink v2-Mini satellites will be onboard. Booster B1082 will be taking its 17th flight and is expected to land on the droneship Of Course I Still Love You approximately eight minutes into the mission. The booster has been in service since early January 2024 and has predominantly launched Starlink missions.

title: Argonaut in LUNA
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: The model stands in LUNA, a cutting-edge lunar training ground that recreates some of the challenging conditions on the Moon. At the heart of the facility is a 700-square metre testbed filled with simulated lunar dust, with a deep floor area that allows for sampling and drilling up to three metres below the surface.

title: Avio Reaches Key Milestone in the Development of its FD1 Rocket Demonstrator
summary:
Italian rocket builder Avio has completed a key hot-fire test of its methane-powered MR10 liquid rocket engine, which will initially power a single-stage demonstrator being developed under the company’s Space Transportation System (STS) programme. The company will now move on to the integration and testing phase of the single-stage FD1 demonstrator. In March 2023, Avio […]
The post Avio Reaches Key Milestone in the Development of its FD1 Rocket Demonstrator appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Italian rocket builder Avio has completed a key hot-fire test of its MR10 liquid rocket engine. The company will now move on to the integration and testing phase of the single-stage FD1 demonstrator. In March 2023, Avio was awarded a €181.6 million contract to develop a two-stage, light-lift rocket powered by its new methalox engines.

title: LUNA: Europe’s Moon on Earth
summary: ESA astronaut Matthias Maurer walks across the dusty terrain of LUNA, Europe's Moon on Earth. Nearby, ESA's Argonaut lander mock-up stands ready as he carefully navigates the simulated regolith - the dust, soil and rock on the Moon's surface. Alongside a fellow operator, he rehearses a moonwalk under the harsh glare of Sun simulators that mimic lunar lighting to test scientific tools designed to analyse lunar soil and rock.
detailed_news: LUNA is located near Cologne, Germany and is operated jointly by ESA and the German Aerospace Center (DLR) The facility is a cornerstone of Europe's contribution to international lunar exploration, supporting astronauts, scientists and engineers in preparing for missions such as NASA's Artemis programme. Outside the facility, the FLEXHab module stands as a future lunar habitat analogue.

title: Sentinel-1D fuelled and ready for encapsulation
summary: The launch campaign of the next satellite to join the Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission is progressing on schedule for launch on Tuesday, 4 November, on board an Ariane 6 rocket.
detailed_news: Sentinel-1D is the mission’s next satellite and is set to join its sibling, Sentinel-1C. The spacecraft Flight Readiness Review took place last week, paving the way for fuelling. The satellite will be encapsulated on Friday, 24 October. The mission is part of the Copernicus family of Sentinel satellites.

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy October 19-25, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of October 19-25, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The Senate is in session this week. […]
detailed_news: The government shutdown continues and will begin its fourth week on Wednesday. The House remains in recess indefinitely except for pro forma sessions. The Senate Commerce Committee will hold a hearing on four nominations including Timothy Petty to be Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere. NASA is shut down other than “excepted” activities that include International Space Station (ISS) operations. The ISS is coming up on 25 years of continuous human presence and the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) will begin the celebration on Tuesday. On Tuesday, former NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine and Axiom Space’s Vice President of Human Spaceflight Peggy Whitson will discuss “The U.S. Enduring Human Presence in Orbit: Reflecting on the Future and Past 25 Years” There are far too many interesting events this week to summarize here, but one more we’ll highlight is the 7th annual Summit for Space Sustainability in Paris. The HTV-X1 launch has not been announced, but it could well take place this week. Check back throughout the week for others we learn about later and add to our Calendar. We do not post comments that include links to other websites since we have no control over that content nor can we verify the security of such links.

title: SpaceX’s SLC-6 redevelopment green light
summary:
In a pivotal step forward for an increase in commercial spaceflight from the West Coast,…
The post SpaceX’s SLC-6 redevelopment green light appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The Department of the Air Force (DAF) has issued the Final Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) and Record of Decision (ROD) authorizing sweeping changes to SpaceX’s launch and landing aspirations at the Vandenberg Space Force Base. The decision clears the path for the redevelopment of the historic Space Launch Complex 6 (SLC-6), enabling up to 100 annual Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy launches from the site. Up to five Falcon Heavy missions per year are now feasible. SLC-6 was originally built to host the US Air Force's Shuttle program. The 1986 Challenger disaster derailed those plans, leading to decommissioning in 1989. ULA’s departure left the pad dormant, opening the door for SpaceX to transform it into a Falcon-capable hub. The dual-pad setup could double West Coast throughput.

title: Something from ‘space’ may have just struck a United Airlines flight over Utah
summary: "NTSB gathering radar, weather, flight recorder data."
detailed_news: The National Transportation Safety Board confirmed Sunday that it is investigating an airliner that was struck by an object in its windscreen, mid-flight, over Utah. The strike occurred Thursday, during a United Airlines flight from Denver to Los Angeles. Images shared on social media showed that one of the two large windows at the front of a 737 MAX aircraft was significantly cracked.

title: Sunset on V2: The End of an Era at Starbase
summary: On Monday, October 13th, 2025 at 6:15pm Booster 15-2 and Ship 38 lifted off from Launch Pad 1 at SpaceX’s Starbase, Texas launch facility and closing out the V1/V2 chapter of the Starship program.
detailed_news: Flight 11 was a largely successful test flight for the Starship Program, with Booster and Ship meeting all of their stated pre-flight goals. With its successful splashdown and Boosters successful demonstrations, this flight marks the close of the 2025 Starship campaign. 2026 will introduce the next iteration of Starship and Superheavy, V3, on the completely redesigned launch pad at Tower 2. Pad 1 began stacking in early 2021, eventually being completed later that year. Ship 24 and Booster 7 took flight on the hazy morning of April 20th, 2023 from Pad 1, marking the first full stack flight from the first iteration of the Orbital Launch Mount (OLM) Ship 25 became the first Starship to reach space, though it would not return.  2025 was set to be a key year for the Starship program, but unfortunately SpaceX’s hopes for a high flight rate were met with setback after setback due to the newly introduced V2 ships. The launch of Flight 7 on January 16th, 2025 marked the first launch of the second version of the Starship upper stage. Starbase’s Gigabay is well under way at the location of the original High Bay. The future for Starship remains in flux, with pressure mounting from NASA to have it ready for Artemis III. 2026 is set to be a new era for not only Starbase, but for the Starship program.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg
summary: The Starlink 11-19 mission will be SpaceX’s 50th launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base in 2025. It’s targeting liftoff from pad Space Launch Complex 4 East at 10:59 a.m. PDT (1:59 p.m. EDT / 1759 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing for its 50th Falcon 9 rocket launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base on Sunday. The Starlink 11-19 mission will add another 28 Starlink satellites to its broadband internet constellation in low Earth orbit. There are more than 8,600 satellites currently in orbit, according to stats maintained by astronomer and expert orbital tracker Jonathan McDowell.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch Falcon 9 rocket on record-breaking 31st flight
summary: The Starlink 10-17 mission will add another 28 broadband satellites into low Earth orbit. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station at 11:49 a.m. EDT (1549 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is set to break another reuse record on Sunday when it launches a Falcon 9 booster for a record-breaking 31st time. The company’s most flown rocket will be used to launch the Starlink 10-17 mission from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 is scheduled for 11:49 a.m. EDT (1549 UTC) The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a greater than 95 percent chance for favorable weather.

detailed_news: ODIN’S EYE project was funded by the European Union under the European Defence Fund. The project aims to develop a sovereign space-based early warning capability that would detect and track the launch of ballistic missiles. In July 2021, an initial €7.5 million was awarded to an OHB System-led consortium.

title: ESA astronauts complete helicopter training in preparation for future lunar missions
summary: Four ESA astronauts have completed a helicopter training course with the German Bundeswehr, Germany’s federal defence forces, marking a key milestone in Europe’s preparations for future missions to the Moon and operations on the lunar surface.
detailed_news: Four ESA astronauts have completed a helicopter training course with the German Bundeswehr. The training is a key milestone in Europe’s preparations for future missions to the Moon and operations on the lunar surface. Helicopter training offers a realistic analogue for the dynamics of planetary landings, requiring capabilities such as vertical take-off and landing.

title: Week in images: 13-17 October 2025
summary: Week in images: 13-17 October 2025

title: Money is pouring into defense but dual-use is the real sweet spot
summary:
It isn’t surprising that more and more space companies are pivoting to defense. Defense budgets are rising across the board, and rising quickly. In fact, the sum of money set to be available is eye-watering. Now that NATO has pledged to spend 5% of GDP by 2035, McKinsey thinks that annual defense spending across the […]

summary:

title: Open Cosmos to Build Spanish Component of the Atlantic Constellation
summary:
UK-headquartered satellite manufacturer Open Cosmos has been selected over Deimos by the European Space Agency (ESA) and the Spanish Space Agency (AEE) to build the Spanish component of the Atlantic Constellation. The Constelación Atlántica (Atlantic Constellation) is a joint initiative between Spain and Portugal to build a 16-satellite Earth observation constellation for coastal surveillance, environmental […]
The post Open Cosmos to Build Spanish Component of the Atlantic Constellation appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: UK-headquartered satellite manufacturer Open Cosmos has been selected over Deimos to build the Spanish component of the Atlantic Constellation. The Constelación Atlántica is a joint initiative between Spain and Portugal to build a 16-satellite Earth observation constellation. Each country has committed €40 million to the project.

title: Earth from Space: Chilean glaciers
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Laguna San Rafael National Park is located on the Pacific coast of southern Chile. It includes the Northern Patagonian Ice Field, a remnant of the Patagonia Ice Sheet. Today, despite the ice field being just a fraction of its previous size, it is still the second largest continuous mass of ice outside the polar regions. The ice mass feeds glaciers that have changed in size between 1987 and 2024.

title: Orion spacecraft arrives at VAB ahead of stacking for Artemis 2
summary: This is the first spacecraft that will carry humans on a mission to the Moon since 1972. The Artemis 2 mission is scheduled for no earlier than Feb. 5, 2026.
detailed_news: Orion spacecraft made its penultimate terrestrial roadtrip late Thursday evening. The spacecraft made the roughly seven-mile journey from the Launch Abort System Facility to the VAB. The trek came almost four years to the day after NASA rolled the Orion spacecraft used on the Artemis 1 mission. The first crewed flight of the Artemis program is set to launch no earlier than Feb. 5 from the Kennedy Space Center. Teams are still working to nail down the specific launch windows available to them in each month. Depending on exactly when they launch, the four-person crew will spend roughly ten days in the confines of the Orion capsule.

title: As shutdown continues, science community keeps focus on long-term budget concerns
summary:
As the government shutdown drags on, scientists and advocates remain focused on the long-term effects of proposed budget cuts at NASA and other agencies.
